comment.author: 25889396@N02
comment._content: What a wonderful portrait. Is this Oswald who died in 1918?

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
This does not ring true as an RAMC uniform.  My guess would be that this is Herbert G R Carr-Ellison, who commissioned into the Northumberland Hussars early in the war.

Oswald was a Northumberland Fusilier.//

comment.author: 63834125@N07
comment._content: If Oswald Fenwicke Clennell Carr Ellison, then he was born in 1895, the 2nd son of John Ralph Carr Ellison and Edith Clennell. Family from Newcastle, (src: familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/m/o/r/Michael-J-Morri...), and so likely related to Colonel Sir Ralph Harry Carr-Ellison, T.D., Lord Lieutenant of Tyne and Wear, (but this needs confirming).

comment.author: 43688219@N00
comment._content: There is a medal index card for an Oswald "Fredericke" Clennell Carr-Ellison listed at the National Archive. He was initially a Second Lieutenant in the Northumberland Fusiliers, rising to Lieutenant\Acting Captain and then Captain. There is no Carr-Ellison or Carr Ellison listed as a member of the Royal Army Medical Corps. He was made a probationary Second Lieutenant in the 3rd Battalion Northumberland Fusiliers w.e.f 2nd October 1914. www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/29080/pages/1843 His appointment as a Second Lieutenant in the Special Reserve, (3rd Battalion Northumberland Fusiliers) was confirmed on completing a period of probation in the edition of the London Gazette dated 28th April 1915. www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/29146/supplements/4151 He was appointed Temporary Captain while commanding a company of the Northumberland Fusiliers with effect from the 2nd October 1915. www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/29532/supplements/3525 His appointment from the Special Reserve to be a Second Lieutenant in the Northumberland Fusilers with effect from the 30th March 1916 was published in the edition of the London Gazette dated 29th March 1916. www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/29525/supplements/3397 If it is Oswald, he would die in 1918 serving with the 2nd Battalion in France. He is remembered on the Alnwick War Memorial. www.fusilier.co.uk/alnwick_northumberland/alnwick_war_mem... There are pictures of Captain Carr-Ellison held in the Durham County Archive from when the 2nd Northumberland Fusilers were serving in Salonika. They are difficult to make out from their web-site, but its not impossible they are same man if the picture above was taken when Oswald first joined up. www.durhamrecordoffice.org.uk/Pages/AdvancedSearchCatalog... www.durhamrecordoffice.org.uk/Pages/AdvancedSearchCatalog... www.durhamrecordoffice.org.uk/Pages/AdvancedSearchCatalog... www.durhamrecordoffice.org.uk/Pages/AdvancedSearchCatalog... www.durhamrecordoffice.org.uk/Pages/AdvancedSearchCatalog... In this picture of him outside his tent he is described as the Commanding Officer of C Company www.durhamrecordoffice.org.uk/Pages/AdvancedSearchCatalog... www.durhamrecordoffice.org.uk/Pages/AdvancedSearchCatalog...

comment.author: 79037172@N04
comment._content: Well, he's clearly not wearing an RAMC cap badge in the photo and in fact no badges of rank at all (nor regimental collar dogs).  That might place the picture in the period of his probationary lieutenancy but I don't know enough to be sure.  The cap badge he is wearing looks much like that of the Northumberland Fusiliers though the "flames" emanating from the ball of the grenade look, to my eyes at least, more like a crown than the traditional design for a fusilier badge.  I must be wrong but I just can't see flames no matter how hard I try.

comment.author: 43688219@N00
comment._content: Possibly a Northumberland Hussars Cap Badge if thats a Crown? www.britishbadgeforum.com/gallery/northumberland_hussars/...

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
Which brings me back to the possibility that this is Herbert G R Carr-Ellison, Northumberland Hussars.  The fact he is wearing a 'belt' and not a Sam Browne, and that he appears to be holding riding gloves and carrying a riding whip, indicate that he may be a probationary cavalry officer in this picture.  Though the Northumberland Hussars cap badge was incised and had a scroll beneath it which this does not appear to have.  

Herbert George R Carr-Ellison was certainly a Captain in February 1915 [LG of 20 Jul 1915].  Possibly of 15 Portland Terrace, Newcastle upon Tyne.  H G C Carr-Ellison was commissioned as a Second Lieutenant in the Northumberland Hussars on 17th February 1900.  Could this photograph be from that date?  He is further listed as a Boer War volunteer as a Lieutenant with 14th Company., 5th Bn. Imperial.Yeomanry.//

comment.author: 77788549@N05
comment._content: The cap badge is almost certainly that of 5th Battalion Imperial Yeomanry. Reference is at www.newmp.org.uk/detail.php?contentId=10785 Lieut Carr-Ellison H. G. C. is listed as a Lieutenant in 14th (Northumberland and Durham) Company, detached from The Northumberland Hussars. 5IY was composed of 13th, 14th, 15th and 16th Companies. Herbert George Carr Carr-Ellison died in Newcastle upon Tyne in 1935.

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
If this is indeed Herbert George Carr Carr-Ellison, he is shown in the London Gazette of 19th January 1914 to be appointed a Captain in the Regular Army to the Northumberland Hussars, having been a Captain (Honorary Captain in the Army) in the Territorial Force.  Appointment wef 19th August 1914.

The 5th Battalion Imperial Yeomanry cap badge is much as he is wearing.  The central device bears a figure 5 above the letters I Y, though early badges have the Prince of Wales feathers instead of the Crown.

Herbert G C Carr-Ellison was born in Kent about 1874.  That would have made him around 27 when he deployed to South Aftrica, and 40 when he was recalled to the Colours in 1914.  This would suggest that the photo in the IWM portfolio is perhaps of a 1900-1901 vintage, taken immediately after joing the Imperial Yeomanry and prior to deployment to South Africa?//

comment.author: 64288588@N05
comment._content:
If this is Herbert George Carr-Ellison an online family tree shows him as Lieutenant born 18 March 1874 in Dover, Kent. Married 7 May 1914 at Aclington, Northumberland to Mabel Mary Tate.

I have been unable to find a MIC record for him.

comment.author: 43688219@N00
comment._content:
Herbert's MIC is under reference WO 372/4/735136 if that helps.

The listing on the National Archive site has him as a Captain in the Northumberland Hussars, then Captain Headquarters Staff and then Captain 21st Lancers.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content:
A son, Theodore R T Carr-Ellis (mother Tate), was born to the couple in Newcastle-upon-Tyne; registered the 1st qr of 1915. 
Death of Theodore R T Carr-Ellis registered 1st qr 1939 in Hitchin. (FreeBMD)
